contentrichtext.text: {{MedalTableTop|F_Morgan_Taylor.jpg|200px|Morgan Taylor}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Athletics at the Summer Olympics|athletics]]}} {{MedalCountry | the {{USA}} }} {{MedalOlympics}}{{MedalGold|[[1924 Summer Olympics|1924 Paris]]|[[Athletics at the 1924 Summer Olympics â€“ Men's 400 metre hurdles|400 m hurdles]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1928 Summer Olympics|1928 Amsterdam]]|[[Athletics at the 1928 Summer Olympics - Men's 400 metre hurdles|400 m hurdles]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1932 Summer Olympics|1932 Los Angeles]]|[[Athletics at the 1932 Summer Olympics - Men's 400 metre hurdles|400 m hurdles]]}} {{MedalBottom}} '''Frederick Morgan Taylor''' (April 17, 1903 – February 16, 1975) was an [[USA|American]] [[hurdling|hurdler]], winner of three [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] medals. [http://www.usatf.org/HallOfFame/TF/showBio.asp?HOFIDs=164] Morgan Taylor, from [[Sioux City, Iowa]], competed in both [[track and field]] and [[American football|football]] at [[Grinnell College]].[http://desmoinesregister.com/sports/extras/hall/1951-track.html#taylor] At the American trials for the [[1924 Summer Olympics]], he broke the world record in the 400 m hurdles on two occasions, making him a favourite for the Olympic gold. In [[Paris]], he broke his World Record again, with a margin of 1.4 seconds to win the gold. However, he had knocked over a hurdle and - because of rules in effect in 1924 - he could not become the World Record holder. Because the second-place finisher was disqualified, the third finisher (and silver medallist) became owner of the new World Record.[http://www.usatf.org/HallOfFame/TF/showBio.asp?HOFIDs=164] Taylor again qualified for the [[1928 Summer Olympics|1928]] and [[1932 Summer Olympics|1932 Olympics]], winning a bronze medal on both occasions, with the titles won by [[David Burghley|Lord Burgley]] and [[Bob Tisdall]]. At his third Olympics, he was honoured for his achievements by carrying the American flag during the opening ceremony of the Games.[http://www.usatf.org/HallOfFame/TF/showBio.asp?HOFIDs=164] ==External links== * [http://www.usatf.org/HallOfFame/TF/showBio.asp?HOFIDs=164 USA Track & Field Hall of Fame] * [http://desmoinesregister.com/sports/extras/hall/1951-track.html#taylor Iowa Sports Hall of Fame] * [http://www.hickoksports.com/history/olmtandf.shtml#400mh Hickock Sports History] {{start box}} {{s-sports|oly}} {{succession box | before = [[Bud Houser]] | title = [[Standard-bearer|Flagbearer]] for {{USA}} | years = [[1932 Summer Olympics|Los Angeles 1932]] | after = [[Al Jochim]] }} {{end box}} {{Footer Olympic Champions 400 m hurdles Men}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Taylor, Morgan | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[Athletics (sport)]] competitor | DATE OF BIRTH = April 17, 1903 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = February 16, 1975 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Taylor, Morgan}} [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]] [[Category:People from Sioux City, Iowa]] [[Category:Grinnell College alumni]] [[Category:American hurdlers]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1924 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1928 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1932 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic track and field athletes of the United States]] [[Category:Olympic gold medalists for the United States]] [[Category:Olympic bronze medalists for the United States]] [[Category:Former sports world record holders]] [[Category:Olympic medalists in athletics (track and field)]]
